meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>year</kanji> that is <kanji>next</kanji> is coming up. What will you do in the year that is next that you did this year too? What do you do that is <vocabulary>annual</vocabulary>?

年次 is a formal term typically used in business settings, such as in 年次報告書 (annual report) or 年次休暇 (annual leave).

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This word is generally used in the names of gardens, like エデンの園 and 桜の園. It's also used in phrases like 学びの園, which means "school" and carries the connotation of being a haven for learning.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>obstruct</kanji>, so what is the verb vocab version? It's <vocabulary>to obstruct</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word share the meaning of <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary>, but this word is primarily used to mean <vocabulary>mountain stream</vocabulary>. Think of it this way, the water for a swamp has to come from somewhere right? It starts out up in the mountains and drains out into a swamp in the valley. The life cycle of a mountain stream into a swamp!

If something does <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>shake</kanji>, it’s probably in <vocabulary>a slump</vocabulary>. If nothing’s shaking, things must be <vocabulary>sluggish</vocabulary>.

不振 is used for times when things are slower or worse than usual. For example, 業績不振 is when a business isn’t doing as well as it usually does, and 食欲不振 is when you don't feel like eating as much as you normally would.

You're taking <kanji>reality</kanji> and trying to <kanji>resemble</kanji> it. To do this, you have to do an <vocabulary>imitation</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>mimicry</vocabulary>, or an <vocabulary>impersonation</vocabulary>.
It has <kanji>simplicity</kanji> and is <kanji>easy</kanji>. Whatever it is, it is <vocabulary>simple</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>easy</vocabulary>.
編集 is <kanji>edit</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to edit</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>cleaning</kanji> (掃除) <kanji>machine</kanji> is a <vocabulary>vacuum cleaner</vocabulary>. Suck that dirt up!
散歩 is "a walk." Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to go for a walk</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go for a stroll</vocabulary>.

華やか is "showy." Now we're doubling it, making it doubly showy. If you make something showy enough, it becomes <vocabulary>gorgeous</vocabulary>, but it also becomes pretty <vocabulary>flamboyant</vocabulary>. So, so, so flamboyant.
除く is "to exclude." This is the te-form, and it means "except." So, something like "please get everything except broccoli," because who wants broccoli?

A <kanji>grave</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is a place where there are graves. It is a <vocabulary>graveyard</vocabulary>.

This word is more direct and informal than 墓地, so using 墓場 for an actual cemetery might come off as disrespectful. It's commonly used in phrases like ゆりかごから墓場まで (from the cradle to the grave) or 墓場まで持っていく (take a secret to the grave).
<kanji>Random</kanji> <kanji>magazine</kanji> is pretty much all magazines. Just a bunch of random stuff inside, making it a <vocabulary>magazine</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>window</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji> is where you go to buy tickets out of the window. You know how there's those windows with holes in them, or the window is the hole itself? That's the kind of <vocabulary>ticket window</vocabulary> I'm talking about.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that 否 (いな) is very formal and somewhat archaic. Today, it's most commonly used in the expression 〜か否か (whether… or <vocabulary>not</vocabulary>).
<kanji>No</kanji>! I will not <kanji>determine</kanji> that. In fact, I <vocabulary>deny</vocabulary> it. This is my <vocabulary>denial</vocabulary>.
"<kanji>No</kanji>" is the <kanji>decision</kanji> I've made. Sorry, but this is <vocabulary>rejection</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, at least on the <kanji>tendon</kanji> side of things.
Your <kanji>muscle</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji> is your <vocabulary>muscle</vocabulary>.

You learned that 垂れる means "to droop" or "to drip." Well, this is the transitive version of that, meaning it takes a direct object. This time, you're the one making something droop or drip, which is why this word means <vocabulary>to dangle something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dribble something</vocabulary>. You can remember it's transitive because of the す ending, which you've seen with lots of transitive verbs by now.

垂らす describes when you dangle something or let something hang in a way which allows gravity to act on it, like hanging a line when fishing. It's also used to describe letting something drip — for example, a little kid letting mucus drip from their nose or a sleeping person dribbling drool out of their mouth.

If you want to <kanji>proclaim</kanji> and <kanji>transmit</kanji> something to a bunch of people, then what better way to do it than <vocabulary>advertising</vocabulary>? Yup, this word refers to various types of <vocabulary>promotion</vocabulary>s, like those for products, services, or ideas. Or, when it comes to transmitting all the things a leader proclaims, you can also call it <vocabulary>propaganda</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>proclaim</kanji> things by <kanji>say</kanji>ing them. This is a <vocabulary>proclamation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>declaration</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>revered</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>revered</vocabulary>!
You are <kanji>revered</kanji> and you have my <kanji>respect</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>respect</vocabulary>.
I have <kanji>loyalty</kanji> to you, so I always tell you the <kanji>truth</kanji>. I am very <vocabulary>faithful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>devoted</vocabulary> to you!

A <kanji>loyalty</kanji> <kanji>announcement</kanji> is the kind of announcement you give to someone who you're loyal to. To this type of person, your announcement would come in the form of <vocabulary>advice</vocabulary> or maybe <vocabulary>admonishment</vocabulary>, if you're upset with what they've done.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>extend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to extend</vocabulary>.

Does the kanji look familiar, kind of like 広い, perhaps? 拡がる is the less common and narrower counterpart of 広がる. It's used to describe the enlargement or extension of the size, area, or range of something.

Go ahead and <kanji>extend</kanji> it and <kanji>stretch</kanji> it. That's how we'll do this <vocabulary>enlargement</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>expansion</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>extension</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Extend</kanji> the lens nice and <kanji>big</kanji> to <vocabulary>zoom</vocabulary> in on the subject, please. That's <vocabulary>magnification</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>enlargement</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>expansion</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>manipulate</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to manipulate</vocabulary>.
This takes the second meaning of the kanji you learned, <vocabulary>chastity</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>manipulate</kanji> the things you <kanji>make</kanji>, you are in <vocabulary>operation</vocabulary> of said things.

This can not only refer to the operation of devices and machinery, but also the <vocabulary>manipulation</vocabulary> of various elements, such as markets, stock prices, and more, with the intention of furthering one's own interests.
Take your <kanji>body</kanji> and <kanji>manipulate</kanji> it around for exercise. This is <vocabulary>Calisthenics</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gymnastics</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Respect</kanji> <kanji>language</kanji> is what you speak to someone you respect and want to elevate. You can do this using this type of Japanese, which is known as <vocabulary>honorific</vocabulary> language.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>livelihood</kanji>. The verb version is <vocabulary>to live</vocabulary>. It's not really "to live" literally, though. It's more like <vocabulary>to live one's life</vocabulary>, rather than just to live.

A <kanji>field</kanji> of <kanji>livelihood</kanji> is so lively! Look at everything jumping around. It is so fresh and new and awesome! That being said, being so lively and fresh and new, it's pretty <vocabulary>unrefined</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rustic</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>Ash</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> tends to be a kind of gray color, wouldn't you say? That makes this word <vocabulary>gray</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>grey</vocabulary>, depending on where you're from).
An <kanji>ash</kanji> <kanji>plate</kanji> is a plate you use for ashes. That's an <vocabulary>ashtray</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ripen</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to ripen</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Ripen</kanji>ed <kanji>language</kanji>s are words that have taken some time to come into their form. They ripened up, starting with just one kanji, but then became two, or three, or more. That is a <vocabulary>compound word</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>compound kanji</vocabulary>. You know that "jukugo" thing I talk about so much? That's this!

Something that has <kanji>not yet</kanji> <kanji>ripen</kanji>ed, is, well, <vocabulary>unripe</vocabulary>. This is often used figuratively to say that someone is either <vocabulary>immature</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inexperienced</vocabulary>, so you'll often encounter those usages!
To <kanji>become</kanji> <kanji>ripe(n)</kanji> is to <vocabulary>ripen</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mature</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>differ</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to differ</vocabulary>.
It <kanji>differ</kanji>s from the normal <kanji>condition</kanji> of things, making it weird. It is an <vocabulary>abnormality</vocabulary>. There is <vocabulary>something wrong</vocabulary>.

Someone who <kanji>differ</kanji>s in <kanji>gender</kanji> from you is of a <vocabulary>different gender</vocabulary>. This is often used to mean the <vocabulary>opposite sex</vocabulary> in the sense of men as viewed by women and vice versa.
My idea of <kanji>righteousness</kanji> is <kanji>different</kanji> from yours. Really, it's just a <vocabulary>different meaning</vocabulary>.
The Japanese <kanji>emperor</kanji> is supposed to have come from the <kanji>heaven</kanji>s, so that just makes this heaven emperor the <vocabulary>emperor of Japan</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>emperor</kanji>'s <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is the <vocabulary>crown prince</vocabulary>, not because he's fat, but because he's the emperor's child.
The <kanji>emperor</kanji>'s <kanji>tribe</kanji> is his family. This family is known as the <vocabulary>imperial family</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>emperor</kanji>'s <kanji>room</kanji> is where the <vocabulary>Imperial Family</vocabulary> gathers.

Note that 皇室 refers to the <vocabulary>Imperial Household</vocabulary> as a family unit, rather than a physical space.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>heaps</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to heap up</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to serve food</vocabulary>, as in you're heaping on food onto someone's plate.
A <kanji>sand</kanji> <kanji>sugar</kanji> is just <vocabulary>sugar</vocabulary>.  Nom nom nom, sugar.
A <kanji>fruit</kanji> <kanji>sugar</kanji> is the type of sugar that's more commonly known as <vocabulary>fructose</vocabulary>. Mmm, delicious fructose.
Something with <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>sugar</kanji> is something that is <vocabulary>sugar free</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unsweetened</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>supply</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to supply</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>obtain</kanji> <kanji>supply</kanji>, you have to put it all together somewhere. You have to put it in <vocabulary>storage</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>enter</kanji> your <kanji>supply</kanji> into the machine, that is your <vocabulary>payment</vocabulary> for the day. Every day you have to enter your supply, otherwise they crack down on you.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

肺 is <kanji>lung</kanji>, がん is "cancer," I suppose because you want it <reading>gone</reading> (がん) from you. That makes this word <vocabulary>lung cancer</vocabulary>, which, with all the smoking in Japan, happens a decent amount.
A <kanji>lung</kanji> <kanji>sick</kanji>ness is bad for those lungs of yours. It means you have <vocabulary>lung disease</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>author</kanji>, but if you think about it, what do authors do? They write about <vocabulary>remarkable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>marked</vocabulary> things, whether it's fiction or nonfiction.
<kanji>Someone</kanji> who is an <kanji>author</kanji> is an <vocabulary>author</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>author</kanji> <kanji>make</kanji>s <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary> in an activity known as <vocabulary>authorship</vocabulary>.

Note that this word isn't a general term for writing! 著作 has a more specific nuance — it's mostly used to talk about a work or the writings of a particular author. You'll also see it often in the compound 著作権, in relation to copyright.

Anywhere with lots of <kanji>steam</kanji> is going to get hot and sticky, so this word means... <vocabulary>to get hot and sticky</vocabulary>!

With 蒸れる, something gets hot and sticky due to trapped heat and moisture, like sweaty armpits under a shirt on a humid day, or a sticky bottom after sitting at a desk for a while.

Additionally, 蒸れる can mean <vocabulary>to be steamed</vocabulary>, like what happens to rice as it softens in a rice cooker.
<kanji>Steam</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is <vocabulary>steam</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>vapor</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Curious about the difference between 蔵 and 倉? Traditionally, the 蔵 kanji was used for sturdy buildings that stored important items. This is where samurai kept their valuables! On the other hand, 倉 originally referred to places to store grain, and usually weren't as robustly made. They're basically interchangeable now, but the 蔵 kanji is more commonly used.
A <kanji>cool</kanji> <kanji>storehouse</kanji> <kanji>storage</kanji> is a place you put things (like food) to keep them cool. This is a <vocabulary>refrigerator</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>ground</kanji> <kanji>storehouse</kanji> refers to a person's name. It may be easier to learn this one reading first because of that. Anyways, this person is <vocabulary>Jizo(u)</vocabulary>, a Bodhisattva, and protector of children.
This looks like it's an adjective, but it's just a tricky word. It's a noun, and it means the same thing as the kanji, making it <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary>.

This <kanji>attire</kanji> is <kanji>put</kanji> inside this <vocabulary>equipment</vocabulary>, where it's changed into something else. This attire <vocabulary>device</vocabulary> is strange and interesting. Imagine something that it does to your attire.
<kanji>Change</kanji> your <kanji>attire</kanji> to look like someone else. This is a <vocabulary>disguise</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>clothes</kanji> which <kanji>attire</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary>. It's how you <vocabulary>dress</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>backside</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji> (think: entrance) is the <vocabulary>back door</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rear entrance</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>cut</kanji> someone from the <kanji>backside</kanji> you're doing a backstabbing, making this word <vocabulary>to backstab</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to betray</vocabulary>.
From the <kanji>backside</kanji> you <kanji>cut</kanji> someone. Wow. What a jerk. What <vocabulary>betrayal</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>treachery</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>backside</kanji> <kanji>street</kanji> (or "avenue") is a street that's not a main street... it's hidden and behind everything, making it an <vocabulary>alley</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
My <kanji>various</kanji> <kanji>buddies</kanji>! Wait, that didn't come out right. <vocabulary>Gentlemen</vocabulary>! <vocabulary>My friends</vocabulary>! There we go, much better.
This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "various _____."
Your <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>rent</kanji> is your <vocabulary>house rent</vocabulary>, though it can be your apartment rent too.
<kanji>Rent</kanji> it and I will <kanji>lend</kanji> it to you. This thing that is being lent and rented? It's a <vocabulary>rental</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>freight</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s <kanji>ship</kanji> is a boat that freights things. It's a <vocabulary>freighter</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Small</kanji> <kanji>wheat</kanji> <kanji>powder</kanji> is <vocabulary>wheat flour</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>flour</vocabulary>.

I don't know why a <kanji>mud</kanji> <kanji>pole</kanji> is a <vocabulary>robber</vocabulary>, but for some reason it is. Just imagine a robber covering himself in mud and standing behind a pole to hide, then jump out, then rob you of everything you've got.
Remember how 驚く is "to be surprised"? This is when you are surprising someone else, doing the surprising, making this word <vocabulary>to surprise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shock</vocabulary>.
掃除 is <kanji>cleaning</kanji>, so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to clean</vocabulary>.

乾く is "to be dried." This is the version where you're doing the drying, making this <vocabulary>to dry something</vocabulary>. You know this because it's annoying to have to dry something yourself, so you <reading>cuss</reading> (かす) endlessly as you do it. "#$@%! Why do I have to waste my time drying this %&$# thing?!"

散る is "to be scattered." 散らかす on the other hand is when you're doing the scattering. So it means <vocabulary>to scatter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make a mess</vocabulary>.

You often hear it when someone talks about making a room messy or leaving things all over the place. You can remember it easily because after a <reading>ruckus</reading> (らかす), people often leave a mess behind.

Remember how 離れる means "to separate," where something separates or moves away from something else? Well, 離す is the transitive version, so it takes a direct object and means <vocabulary>to separate something</vocabulary>. You can remember this because if you try to separate two people who don't want to be separated, they might sue (す) you in response!

離す is used when you detach or put space between people or objects. This could be literal, like when you 離す your bed from the wall, or more figurative, like when you carelessly 離す your eyes from something important. 

It can also mean <vocabulary>to let go</vocabulary> of something, because you're "separating" your hand from it. This use is very similar to 放す, but it doesn't have that nuance of setting something free — it's just the neutral act of letting go of something.
<kanji>Simplicity</kanji> is <kanji>simple</kanji>, making this <vocabulary>simple</vocabulary> as well.

A <kanji>mud</kanji>dy <kanji>bog</kanji> is a way of describing a <vocabulary>quagmire</vocabulary>. It’s a bog with almost no water left, having become all muddy and sticky. Gross (and dangerous)!

This word is typically used figuratively to describe a situation where a conflict becomes messy and difficult to resolve, or a problem from which it is difficult to extricate oneself.
An <kanji>edit</kanji> is 編集. <kanji>Someone</kanji> who does those edits is an <vocabulary>editor</vocabulary>!
What do people usually scatter in a rush (らし)? Leaflets and flyers. Handing them out takes way too much time, so if you just scatter them all over the place your job will be done so much faster!

The most important part of your <kanji>military</kanji> <kanji>attire</kanji> are your <vocabulary>arms</vocabulary> (not the ones attached to your body, your guns and stuff). Arms are what make you a real military person.
When something <kanji>differ</kanji>s from <kanji>normal</kanji> it's called <vocabulary>abnormal</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same.
The <kanji>groin</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is simply the <vocabulary>groin</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crotch</vocabulary>.

Did you know that your <kanji>crotch</kanji> is <kanji>connected</kanji> via various <kanji>joint</kanji>s? That makes this word your <vocabulary>hip joints</vocabulary> or, more generally, just your <vocabulary>hip</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You already know 理屈 means "logic" or "argument." So what's <kanji>flatulence</kanji> logic? It's an <vocabulary>illogical argument</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>far-fetched argument</vocabulary>, or sometimes a <vocabulary>lame excuse</vocabulary>. It's all just hot air!

A <kanji>hometown</kanji> <kanji>potato</kanji> is a <vocabulary>taro</vocabulary>. In Japan, taro is the kind of potato that everyone has in their hometown, because it's been around for such a long time and it'll grow anywhere.

In English, "taro" can sometimes be used for other root vegetables too, but just keep in mind this word refers specifically to the <vocabulary>Japanese taro</vocabulary> — a small, starchy, potato-like vegetable.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Lodger Who Pays Nothing For Room And Board

meaning_mnemonic: To stay <kanji>alive</kanji> in some <kanji>climate</kanji>s, some have no choice but to be a <vocabulary>freeloader</vocabulary>. That is, <vocabulary>a lodger who pays nothing</vocabulary>. If you live somewhere with an inhospitable climate but you can't afford to pay rent, your only option is to live with someone for free.

When a <kanji>warm</kanji> temper is applied extra <kanji>thick</kanji>, it leads to a person having a <vocabulary>mild-mannered</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> personality.

Note that this is a more formal term, so you'll usually encounter it in writing.

Something of <kanji>heaven</kanji>'s <kanji>nature</kanji> is indeed <vocabulary>natural</vocabulary>, with no human intervention involved.

Although this word is technically a noun, it's often used as an adjective. That's also what distinguishes it from 自然. So you'll often see 天然 used to say that something is "natural" or "of nature", while 自然 will often be used to talk about nature in general, like saying that nature is beautiful.

You have the kanji for <kanji>wipe</kanji>, and this is the verb version of that, which makes this <vocabulary>to wipe</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to mop up</vocabulary>.

You've already learned 拭く, which is a general word for the act of wiping, whether you're wiping a table or wiping your forehead. 拭う, on the other hand, is more commonly used in writing to describe the act of wiping away and removing something specific like sweat, tears, filth, or even doubts.

Remember how 貯める means "to save up"? This is a lot like that, except the focus is on the thing that's being saved up. That's why it means <vocabulary>to be saved up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to add up</vocabulary>. To remember this is the intransitive version, just think about how it's easy for money to be saved up if you put it in the <reading>mar</reading>ket (まる).

貯まる will often refer to money, like in 資金が貯まる (funds get saved up). But you'll also see it in phrases like マイルが貯まる (frequent flier miles add up).

When there's only a <kanji>slight</kanji> <kanji>distinction</kanji> between you and your opponent, victory is sure to be decided by a <vocabulary>narrow margin</vocabulary>.

僅差 refers to a very <vocabulary>small difference</vocabulary> — like winning or losing by just a hair. You'll hear it in sports, competitions, tests, or rankings when the gap is tiny: a few points, a few seconds, or almost nothing at all. It is a relatively formal word that shows up more in writing, news, and commentary than in casual chats.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>make money</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is pretty similar: <vocabulary>to make a profit</vocabulary>.

儲ける means <vocabulary>to gain something</vocabulary> in a way that feels profitable or advantageous. It's most common in money talk, like 株で儲ける (make a profit from stocks), but it can also describe other kinds of lucky or beneficial gains. For example, you might 一日儲ける (gain an extra day) thanks to a lucky turn of events or an efficient way of doing something.
